awd_titl_txt: Planning: Integrating Distributed Energy Resources with Grid-Interactive Efficient Buildings for Net Zero Energy and Community Resilience
awd_abstract_narration:
There is an urgent imperative to tackle global warming, climate change, and the growing energy demand. The purpose of this planning grant is to initiate a new research effort that will contribute to the integration of renewable energy resources with building heating, air conditioning, and lighting systems. This integration will support the decarbonization of buildings, bolster climate mitigation efforts, foster cost reductions and support equitable access to resilient power systems for remote underserved communities. This planning grant is a first step in creating and sustaining a long-term multi-disciplinary research program at Tennessee State University (TSU), a historically Black university, that combines faculty expertise in renewable power, power grid security and resilience, and building energy systems. The grant supports the TSU faculty team in fully developing their long-term research plans and seeking partnerships with national laboratories and other universities for a multi-year collaborative research effort.

This planning grant aims to build collaborations and establish high impact research at Tennessee State University with access to industry partners and national labs. The planning grant provides an opportunity to strategically plan the collaboration's scope and align research areas related to the integration of Distributed Energy Resources (DERs) and Grid-interactive efficient buildings (GEBs) by assessing available resources and facilities. DERs have been increasing in popularity as a sustainable source of energy to combat issues that could affect future generations. Most sources of energy that are supplied in the U.S. are nonrenewable such as coal, and fossil fuels, which make up about 88%, and the other 12% comes from renewable sources. DERs can include behind-the-meter renewable generation such as rooftop solar photovoltaic (PV) units, wind turbines, fuel cells, and battery energy storage. Buildings account for 75% of all U.S. electricity use and 40% of the nation's total energy and account for 35% of the country's carbon dioxide emissions. The large portion of energy use provides promising demand flexibility, resilience and energy saving potential. GEBs are energy efficient buildings with smart technologies, which actively employ DERs to optimize energy consumption for grid services, cater to occupant requirements and preferences, contribute to climate mitigation efforts, and achieve cost reductions. By establishing strong relationships and effective collaboration practices during the planning phase, the grant serves as a foundation for long-term collaboration between the involved research institutions. This sets the stage for future joint projects, grant applications, and sustained intellectual collaboration.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This planning grant project aimed to establish a robust multidisciplinary research program at Tennessee State University (TSU) focusing on integrating distributed energy resources (DERs) with grid-interactive efficient buildings (GEBs). By leveraging collaborations with leading national laboratories and building on TSU’s strengths, the project advanced understanding and capabilities in renewable energy integration, energy efficiency, and resilience.

Intellectual Merit

This initiative addressed pressing challenges in energy systems, including the integration of DERs like solar photovoltaics, battery storage, and smart grids with energy-efficient building systems. The team explored innovative strategies for enhancing demand flexibility and energy management, including smart building controls and occupant-centric strategies. These efforts align with NSF and societal goals of achieving sustainable and resilient energy systems, with specific attention to underserved communities.

Key intellectual contributions include:

  • Assessing the interoperability challenges and high costs associated with DERs and GEBs.
  • Investigating emerging technologies like grid-interactive HVAC systems, thermal energy storage, and advanced battery facilities.
  • Developing a research roadmap to integrate DERs with GEBs for resilient and efficient energy solutions.

Broader Impacts

The project emphasized addressing climate change by fostering a transition to renewable energy while advancing education and workforce development in historically underrepresented communities. Specific impacts include:

  • Engaging TSU’s diverse student population in hands-on research, with a focus on underrepresented groups in STEM fields.
  • Establishing interdisciplinary collaborations among TSU faculty in electrical engineering, architectural engineering, and other fields.
  • Conducting outreach to local and regional communities to enhance awareness of energy efficiency and renewable energy solutions.

Collaborations with national laboratories, including PNNL, NIST, ORNL, and NREL, facilitated knowledge exchange and provided access to cutting-edge research facilities. Visits and interactions with these labs informed the design of future research projects and contributed to a comprehensive understanding of the technical and practical aspects of DER and GEB integration.

Outcomes of the Award

Over the life of the award, the project achieved the following:

  1. Successfully submitted the NSF EiR grant to strengthened TSU’s capacity for high-impact research through partnerships with premier national laboratories.
  2. If we receive this grant, it will provide students with valuable research experience in energy systems, preparing them for careers in renewable energy and energy efficiency.
  3. Contribute to the knowledge base on integrating DERs with GEBs, with publications and presentations advancing the field.

The work completed under this planning grant lays the foundation for a larger-scale EiR proposal to continue this important research. The interdisciplinary framework and collaborative partnerships developed during this project will support TSU’s long-term goal of becoming a leader in renewable energy research and education.
